ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3 hours on an average week and much more for the final paper.
2 for readings/summaries, but many more for term paper (~20)
More than 10 hours per week this included: reading articles, reading responses, and meeting with partner for systematic reviews.
5-10. Towards the end of the semester the amount of hours spent per week increased.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: RPE is a fantastic professor who cares deeply about the subject matter of the course and about students. I really appreciated his interest and enthusiasm, and particularly his admiration for colleagues who produced really strong work. It was a wonderful opportunity to learn from someone who is currently deeply involved in developing evidence and policy.

I love the material, but lectures are a bit boring. I suggest making it more interactive. Also, maybe having more checkpoints for the systematic review would be helpful, and evaluating partners as workload was unevenly distributed in a couple of groups that I am aware of. Presentations also seem to have been graded rather strictly.

not many strengths. regret taking the course, did not learn much. lectures were helpful and some were interesting. end project of writing systematic review was good for understanding a maternal child specific topic, but a relative waste of time. would have been much better if the instructor incorporated a final project that reflected everything taught in the powerpoints. for example, a team based project in which we evaluated a public health strategy related to maternal child nutrition would have helped us learn a lot
Great course. Very interesting and applicable material. The systemmatic review was complicated but helpful.

strengths are the professor's knowledge of the subject, and weekly assignments to understand content more.weaknesses are professor always ran over time, and group work was always at the end of class, making it rushed. class was very didactic and not engaging. maybe group work first would help this.

The course has good intentions, but I can honestly say that I didn't learn much at all. The systematic review was almost pointless- if you want a course on writing a systematic review, then create a course that specifically revolves around that. I was expecting to come out with a great deal of knowledge on Maternal and Child health nutrition, but I didn't learn much outside of what Google could have taught me.

I liked this course a lot, and appreciated insights provided by the instructor. The set-up of the course is good, with room for students to explore an area of interest in the systematic review, while integrating information learned throughout the semester.
1. Have more time for discussion/ questions during class time.2. Not going over class time would be great.

Overall I enjoyed the course and was able to engage with what was learnt. I felt like at the end of the class I understand how to conduct a systematic review and walked away with a research skill I didn't previously have.The class was a bit didactic in the way it was structured with lectures in the beginning and group work at the end. I think having the group work in the beginning might be helpful in engaging the class and getting everyone to think about the topic and then learn more from the lecture.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  I think he's fantastic. Always well prepared and interested in student ideas.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Expert in the field, very friendly
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  good lecturer
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Great instructor. Very interesting lectures.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Good professor with lots of knowledge on content. would be helpful to engage students more.He's very understanding and really wants students to succeed. Passionate about course material.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  This course just didn't execute very well. He had good intentions, but he should revamp how people learn specific topics each week because I didn't learn much from the weekly summaries.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla is a wonderful resource, I appreciated learning from someone who approaches public health from a perspective that integrates good research with effectiveness in the community.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  1. Extremely knowledgeable on the topic2. Approachable

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Rafael is a fantastic lecturer and very attentive to student needs. He is extremely approachable and was really helpful answering any questions and providing guidance for the assignments.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  Sefa was very helpful when I sought her advice. Very approachable.
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  Always open to help where needed
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  good TA, always available
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  Very helpful. Knows a lot about systemmatic reviews.
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  Was not usually involved in lectures, but helpful on days she was.
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  I didn't have a lot of contact with Josefa, but she seemed to be willing and available to help students.
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  1. approachable2. knowledgeable on subject and willing to give feedback to improve
Instructor: Josefa Lynn Martinez  Sefa was a great TA! She was available for meetings and togive guidance on assignments and was a really great help with the systematic review.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I loved this course and I would highly recommend it to other students. I wish that the final project was not partner-based because it leaves me with a bad taste in my mouth. I feel like the final project that we turn in will not reflect how hard I have worked on it and that bums me out.
Weekly lectures about different maternal child public health topics. Graded based off a variety of things: exam, presentation, paper. The systematic review is intense though.
waste of time, do not recommend it
Good course content. Not very engaging. Systematic review is a lot of work.
I'm on the fence- there's more busy work than learning.

I would recommend if fellow student is interested in maternal-child nutrition. For someone who is not interested in the subject or not planning on learning about systematic reviews, this class is not for them.

I would recommend the course to other students who were interested in learning more on Maternal and Child Nutrition because it not only went over very interesting and important topics in the field, but also helped students learn research skills through conducting and presenting a systematic review.
